can you target planets?

Is it possible for the computer to take use input? I checked the github and wiki, and I didn't see any sort of documentation on it.

Is it possible for the computer to take use input? I checked the github and wiki, and I didn't see any sort of documentation on it.

what do you mean?

what do you mean?

Nevermind, I just figured it out. I'm used to C++, where you set a variable, tell the program to output a statement asking for the user to give an input for that variable, then have the program wait for an input. Instead, you can use an undeclared variable in a program, define it outside the program, and everything will be hunky dory.
Why does the zip file I downloaded from spaceport is empty? (uploads_2013_11_kOS_0_9.zip has only 22 bytes)
I saw that 0.9 was released and I was all excited to try it out, but the file on spaceport is broken. It's only 44 bytes long so I'm pretty sure that's not going to work.
Confirming this as well, 0.9 kOS update download link is broken - empty zip file.
Confirmed here too. Keep up the good work, still!
Hooray, 0.9!
I haven't had a chance to try it yet but there appears to be a new full-size ZIP file on the spaceport page now.

I've been having trouble using if.. then... in side loops. For example the demo launch by Kevin Laity

set tVal to 1.

lock throttle to tVal.
lock steering to up + R(0,0,180).
stage.
print "Launch!".

until altitude > 10000
{
  if verticalspeed > 210
  {
    set tVal to tVal Ã¢â‚¬â€œ 0.02.
  }.
}.

lock steering to up + R(0,0,180) + R(0,-60,0).
print "Beginning gravity turn.".

wait 5.

until throttle = 1
{
  set tVal to tVal + 0.02.
  if tVal > 1 { set tVal to 1. }.
}.
// Program proceeds with staging and reaching orbit from here.

Produces the error unrecognised term 'tVal 0.02'

I tried wrapping brackets around the calculation

until altitude > 10000
{
  if verticalspeed > 210
  {
    set tVal to (tValÃ¢â‚¬â€œ0.02).
  }.
}.

but that doesn't seem to help.
